references: Vandewege, M.W., T.M. Swannack, K.L. Greuter, D.J. Brown, and M.R.J. Forstner. 2013. Breeding site fidelity and terrestrial movement of an endangered amphibian, the Houston toad (Bufo houstonensis). Herpetological Conservation and Biology 8(2):435-446.
Hillis DM, Hillis AM, Martin RF (1984) Reproductive ecology and hybridization of the endangered Houston toad (Bufo houstonensis). Journal of Herpetology 18:56-72.
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. 1984. Recovery Plan for the Houston Toad (Bufo houstonensis). 73 pp.
Brown, D.J., T.M. Swannack, and M.R.J. Forstner. 2013. Predictive models for calling and movement activity of the endangered Houston toad. The American Midland Naturalist, 169(2):303-321.

Swannack, T.M. 2007. Modeling aspects of the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of the endangered Houston toad. In: Wildlife and Fisheries Sciences, p. 175. Texas A&M University, College Station TX.

Forstner, M.R.J., and T.M. Swannack. 2004. The Houston Toad in Context: 2000-2004. Submitted to the Capitol Area Council, Boy Scouts of America and Texas Parks and Wildlife Department in completion of United States Fish and Wildlife Service Section 6 Grant "Habitat use of the Houston toad".
habitat_description: Anaxyrus houstonensis breed and develop in “shallow, ephemeral pools or permanent water bodies with slow flowing pools or eddies” (Forstner and Swannack, 2004). These water bodies must persist for at least 60 days to allow egg and tadpole development (Hillis et al., 1984). Calls have been documented in lakes, manmade ponds, roadside ditches, flooded fields/pastures, and rain pools in forest, clearings, or residential areas (USFWS, 1984). In addition to its hydrologic requirements, the species is limited to areas of friable, sandy soils for burrowing and aestivation (Hillis et al., 1984; USFWS, 1984; Forstner and Swannack, 2004). Habitat near breeding sites includes forests of loblolly, post oak, blackjack oak, and/or red cedar (Hillis et al., 1984; Forstner and Swannack, 2004; Brown et al., 2013). Such forests are often interspersed with grassy patches, pasture, or coastal prairie (USFWS, 1984; Forstner and Swannack, 2004), with the species not documented farther than 25 m from the forest edge (Forstner and Swannack, 2004; Vanderwege et al., 2013). Furthermore, individuals only travel up to 200 m from ponds (Swannack, 2007).
